facts.text: Hirday Ram was the owner of the suit property.

anchor.surface_text: One Hirday Ram was the owner of the suit property. He had three wives, namely, Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi.

facts.text: Hirday Ram had three wives: Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi.

anchor.surface_text: He had three wives, namely, Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi. Kubja had pre- deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami.

facts.text: Kubja pre-deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami.

anchor.surface_text: Kubja had pre- deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami. During his life time, Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938

facts.text: Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938 bequeathing part of property to Tikami and remaining to Pari and Uttamdassi for maintenance without power to alienate, to revert to Tikami after their death.

anchor.surface_text: During his life time, Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938 whereby he bequeathed a part of his property to his daughter Tikami and the remaining property was given to his two other wives, named above, for their maintenance with the companydition that they would number have the power to alienate the same in any manner. As per the Will, after the death of the above two wives of Hirday Ram, the property was to revert back to his daughter Tikami as absolute owner.

facts.text: Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari died in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari in 1939, the property in question came to be vested with the third wife, Uttamdassi as per the terms of the Will.

facts.text: Property vested with Uttamdassi after death of Hirday Ram and Pari as per Will.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari in 1939, the property in question came to be vested with the third wife, Uttamdassi as per the terms of the Will.

facts.text: Uttamdassi sold a part of the property to Sandup on 28.11.1958, predecessor-in-interest of respondent Nos.1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: After the companying into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, Uttamdassi claiming to be the absolute owner sold a part of the property to one Sandup on 28.11.1958 predecessor-in-interest of respondent Nos.1 and 2 herein.

facts.text: Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi.

anchor.surface_text: The said Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi who on 2.12.1958 made a gift of another property in favour of respondent No.3 herein who in turn sold to it respondent No.4.

facts.text: Uttamdassi made a gift of another property to respondent No.3 on 2.12.1958, who sold it to respondent No.4.

anchor.surface_text: The said Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi who on 2.12.1958 made a gift of another property in favour of respondent No.3 herein who in turn sold to it respondent No.4.

facts.text: Appellant is daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein is a daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram filed a suit challenging the alienation made by Uttamdassi seeking a decree for declaration that the alienation made by Uttamdassi would number effect her reversionary rights.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit challenging alienation by Uttamdassi; trial court decreed on 12.7.1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein is a daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram filed a suit challenging the alienation made by Uttamdassi seeking a decree for declaration that the alienation made by Uttamdassi would number effect her reversionary rights. The suit was decreed by the trial companyrt on 12.7.1961.

facts.text: Appeal by Uttamdassi dismissed on 25.1.1963; declaratory decree final.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal filed by Uttamdassi was dismissed on 25.1.1963. Thus the said declaratory decree became final as it was number put to challenge in further appeal in the High Court.

facts.text: Uttamdassi gifted property sold to Sandup to respondent No.5 on 24.5.1975.

anchor.surface_text: On 24.5.1975 Uttamdassi gifted the property sold by her to Sandup in 1958 in favour of respondent No.5.

facts.text: Appellant filed second suit challenging 1975 gift; trial court dismissed, first appellate court accepted on appeal, gift void ab initio, decree final.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein again filed a suit challenging the said alienation also and seeking a declaration that the said alienation made by Uttamdassi would number effect her reversionary rights. The trial companyrt dismissed the suit but an appeal preferred by the appellant herein the was accepted by the First Appellate Court and the gift made by the Uttamdassi in favour of respondent No.5 was held to be void ab initio and a declaration was given that the alienation made by Uttamdassi would number effect reversionary rights of the plaintiff. This decree also became absolute as the same was number put to any further challenge.

facts.text: Uttamdassi gifted part of property to respondent No.5 by Will on 27.12.1986.

anchor.surface_text: It is relevant to mention herein that Uttamdassi had gifted a part of the property in favour of respondent No.5 by way of a Will on 27.12.1986.

facts.text: Uttamdassi died on 1.1.1987.

anchor.surface_text: She died on 1.1.1987.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit for possession after Uttamdassi's death as nearest reversioner based on two declaratory decrees; trial court dismissed on 22.8.1989.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Uttamdassi, appellant the granddaughter of the original owner Hirday Ram brought a suit for possession of the suit property being the nearest reversioner and on the basis of the two earlier declaratory decrees obtained by her. The trial companyrt dismissed the suit on 22.8.1989.

facts.text: Trial court relied on V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy (1977 3 SCC 99) holding Uttamdassi absolute owner under Section 14(1) HSA.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon a judgment of this Court in the case of V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy  1977  3 SCC 99  holding, inter alia, that though the suit property was given to the wives of Hirday Ram as limited owners but in view of Section 14 1  of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 Uttamdassi became the absolute owner of the suit property and had the right to alienate the same by way of sale, gift or will.

facts.text: First appellate court dismissed appellant's appeal on 30.9.1991 holding declaratory decrees do not operate as res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal filed by the appellant was dismissed on 30.9.1991 by the First Appellate Court holding inter alia that the declaratory decrees obtained by the appellant did number operate as res judicata inter se parties as the same were passed in suits filed by the appellant as presumptive reversioner of the widow of Hirday Ram and the present suit was filed after her death for possession as owner.

facts.text: High Court dismissed second appeal holding earlier decrees not res judicata due to pure question of law and overruling by Tulasamma case.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred a regular second appeal which has been dismissed by the impugned judgment of the High Court holding inter alia that interpretation of Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 was a pure question of law and the earlier decrees obtained on the interpretation of law in the case of Mst. Karmi vs. Amru Ors.  AIR 1971 SC 745  cannot operate as re judicata in the face of the companytrary interpretation put to Section 14 in the later decision of this Court in V.Tulasammas case  supra .

facts.text: Division Bench referred appeals to larger bench on 27th October, 2004 due to contradictory views in Teg Singh, Kesar Singh, Balwant Singh.

anchor.surface_text: SANTOSH HEGDE, J. Noticing certain companytradictory views in three different judgments of this Court in Teg Singh vs. Charan Singh  1977  2 SCC 732, Kesar Singh vs. Sadhu  1996  7 SCC 711  and Balwant Singh vs. Daulat Singh  1997  7 SCC 137 , a Division Bench of 2-Judges of this Court referred the instant appeals for disposal by a larger bench by its referral order dated 27th October, 2004, hence, this appeal is before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court in V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy 1977 3 SCC 99 held that under Section 14(1) HSA, limited estate enlarges to absolute ownership.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon a judgment of this Court in the case of V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy  1977  3 SCC 99  holding, inter alia, that though the suit property was given to the wives of Hirday Ram as limited owners but in view of Section 14 1  of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 Uttamdassi became the absolute owner of the suit property and had the right to alienate the same by way of sale, gift or will.

issues.text: Whether res judicata operates where the earlier declaratory decree is contrary to existing law or subsequent authoritative interpretation of Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act

anchor.surface_text: This argument is obviously based on the principle of res judicata. Ordinarily such an argument ought to be accepted but there are some exceptions in regard to the application of this principle. One such exception would be where the earlier declaration obtained by the court is established to be contrary to an existing law. In Mathura Prasad Bajoo Jaiswal Ors. vs. Dossibai B.Jeejeebhoy 1970 1 SCC 613 this Court held Where the law is altered since the earlier decision, the earlier decision will not operate as res judicata between the same parties

issues.text: Whether a decree on a pure question of law such as interpretation of Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act operates as res judicata in subsequent proceedings

Karmi vs. Amru Ors. AIR 1971 SC 745 cannot operate as re judicata in the face of the contrary interpretation put to Section 14 in the later decision of this Court in V.Tulasammas case supra

issues.text: Whether a declaratory decree obtained by a reversioner entitles the holder to maintain a suit for possession after the death of the limited owner when the estate has enlarged under Section 14(1) of the Hindu Succession Act

anchor.surface_text: by virtue of Section 14(1) the limited right got by Uttamdassi under the Will got enlarged to an absolute right in the suit property. Thus, she became absolute owner of the property, hence, any declaratory right obtained earlier by the reversioner as contemplated in the Will cannot be the basis on which the suit for possession could be maintained unless, of course, the claimants in the suit for possession established a better title independent of the declaratory decree obtained by them.

issues.text: Whether principles of res judicata apply to decrees that are nullities due to lack of jurisdiction or being contrary to law

anchor.surface_text: principles of res judicata under Section 11 of the CPC will not be attracted and it is open to the defendant in such suits to establish that the decree relied upon by the plaintiff is not a good law or court granting such decree did not have the jurisdiction to grant such decree. When an order is passed without jurisdiction, the same becomes a nullity. When an order is a nullity, it cannot be supported by invoking the procedural principles like, estoppel, waiver or res judicata.

It is contended that the declaration of law made by this Court in V.Tulasammas case not being retrospective the judgments obtained by the appellant even if it is contrary to the said judgment in Tulasammas case the same having become final cannot be held to be invalid in law

arguments.claim: Teg Singh supports: declaratory decree by reversioner continues operative despite subsequent law change.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention the learned counsel for the appellant relied on a judgment of this Court in Teg Singhs case  supra  which was a case in which a declaratory decrees obtained under the Punjab Custom  Power to Contest  Act, 1920, as amended by Act 12 of 1973, held that though a suit to contest an alienation of immovable property under the customary law may not lie after the coming into force of the Amending Act of 1973, but a declaratory decree already obtained by a reversioner would continue to be operative as the Amending Act does not render such a decree a nullity.

arguments.court_reasoning: Teg Singh based on special enactment not applicable here.

arguments.claim: Balwant Singh similar: declaratory decree does not convey title; suit for possession not maintainable post-enlargement under HSA S.14(1).

anchor.surface_text: However, the decision of this Court in the case of Balwant Singh  supra  would have a bearing on the merits of this case wherein it is held that suit for possession would not be maintainable on the basis of a declaratory decree as the declaratory decree did not convey any title in favour of the reversioners. ... Almost similar is the facts of this case inasmuch as in this case also since on the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act by virtue of Section 14 1  the limited right got by Uttamdassi under the Will got enlarged to an absolute right in the suit property.

arguments.claim: Res judicata does not apply where earlier declaration contrary to existing law; law altered post-decree.

anchor.surface_text: This argument is obviously based on the principle of res judicata. Ordinarily such an argument ought to be accepted but there are some exceptions in regard to the application of this principle. One such exception would be where the earlier declaration obtained by the court is established to be contrary to an existing law. In Mathura Prasad Bajoo Jaiswal Ors. vs. Dossibai B.Jeejeebhoy 1970 1 SCC 613 this Court held Where the law is altered since the earlier decision, the earlier decision will not operate as res judicata between the same parties

arguments.claim: Second declaratory decree contrary to V. Tulasamma declaration of law under S.14.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be noticed that in the present case when the first declaratory decree was obtained, the law as it stood then right of Uttamdassi remained a limited right, in the suit property hence, a declaratory decree was given in favour of the plaintiffs in that suit, but by the time the second declaratory decree was obtained by the appellant herein, this Court by the judgment in V.Thulasammas case had declared the law under Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act holding that the estate of persons similarly situated as Uttamdassi got enlarged

arguments.claim: Res judicata does not preclude challenge to decree on pure question of law or where court lacked jurisdiction/illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the above in the very same case of Mathura Prasad  supra , this Court at para 11 held Where, however, the question is one purely of law and it relates to the jurisdiction of the court or a decision of the court sanctioning something which is illegal, by resort to the rule of res judicata a party affected by the decision will not be precluded from challenging the validity of that order under the rule of res judicata, for a rule of procedure cannot supercede the law of the land.

arguments.claim: Pure question of law like S.14 interpretation; res judicata/estoppel do not sustain decision lacking jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In Chief Justice of Andhra Pradesh Ors. vs. V.A.Dixitulu Ors.  1979 2 SCC 34  at para 24 discussing the effect of Section 11 of the CPC on a pure question of law or a decision given by a court without jurisdiction this Court held Moreover, this is a pure question of law depending upon the interpretation of Article 371D. If the argument holds good, it will make the decision of the Tribunal as having been given by an authority suffering from inherent lack of jurisdiction. Such a decision cannot be sustained merely by the doctrine of res judicata or estoppel as urged in this case.

arguments.claim: Res judicata is procedural; does not apply to jurisdictional errors or prior proceedings jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The Principle of res judicata belongs to the domain of procedure. When the decision relates to the jurisdiction of a court to try an earlier proceedings, the principle of res judicata would not come into play. See Mathura Prasad Bajoo Jaiswal  supra .

arguments.claim: Decree without jurisdiction is nullity; not protected by res judicata, estoppel, waiver.

anchor.surface_text: When an order is passed without jurisdiction, the same becomes a nullity. When an order is a nullity, it cannot be supported by invoking the procedural principles like, estoppel, waiver or res judicata.

arguments.claim: V. Tulasamma prospective only; first declaratory decree based on then-law prevails and final.

arguments.claim: ECIL supports prospective overruling protects prior final decrees.

arguments.court_reasoning: ECIL does not help; declaratory not attaining finality for possession suits.

arguments.claim: Defendant can challenge prior declaratory decree if contrary to prevailing law or court lacked jurisdiction; no res judicata under S.11 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the law is clear on this point i.e. if a suit is based on an earlier decree and such decree is contrary to the law prevailing at the time of its consideration as to its legality or is a decree granted by a court which has no jurisdiction to grant such decree, principles of res judicata under Section 11 of the CPC will not be attracted and it is open to the defendant in such suits to establish that the decree relied upon by the plaintiff is not a good law or court granting such decree did not have the jurisdiction to grant such decree.

holdings.text: The earlier declaratory decrees obtained by the appellant do not operate as res judicata in the suit for possession and do not entitle her to possession as they are contrary to the law declared in V. Tulasamma's case.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the law is clear on this point i.e. if a suit is based on an earlier decree and such decree is contrary to the law prevailing at the time of its consideration as to its legality or is a decree granted by a court which has no jurisdiction to grant such decree, principles of res judicata under Section 11 of the CPC will not be attracted and it is open to the defendant in such suits to establish that the decree relied upon by the plaintiff is not a good law or court granting such decree did not have the jurisdiction to grant such decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Earlier decrees contrary to prevailing law under Section 14 HSA as interpreted in V. Tulasamma; res judicata does not apply to illegal or jurisdictional errors per Mathura Prasad and other precedents.

holdings.text: The limited right obtained by Uttamdassi under the Will enlarged into an absolute right under Section 14(1) of the Hindu Succession Act.

anchor.surface_text: Almost similar is the facts of this case inasmuch as in this case also since on the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act by virtue of Section 14 1  the limited right got by Uttamdassi under the Will got enlarged to an absolute right in the suit property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Section 14(1) HSA and V. Tulasamma to facts where property given for maintenance without alienation power.

holdings.text: A suit for possession cannot be maintained solely on the basis of an earlier declaratory decree obtained by a reversioner when the limited owner's estate has enlarged into absolute ownership under Section 14(1) HSA unless better title is independently established.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, she became absolute owner of the property, hence, any declaratory right obtained earlier by the reversioner as contemplated in the Will cannot be the basis on which the suit for possession could be maintained unless, of course, the claimants in the suit for possession established a better title independent of the declaratory decree obtained by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Balwant Singh where declaratory decree does not convey title; enlargement under HSA overrides reversionary rights in Will.

holdings.text: Principles of res judicata do not apply where the earlier decree is contrary to existing law or where the law has been altered since the earlier decision.

anchor.surface_text: One such exception would be where the earlier declaration obtained by the court is established to be contrary to an existing law. In Mathura Prasad Bajoo Jaiswal Ors. vs. Dossibai B.Jeejeebhoy  1970   1 SCC 613  this Court held Where the law is altered since the earlier decision, the earlier decision will not operate as res judicata between the same parties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exception to res judicata per Mathura Prasad; second decree post-Tulasamma contrary to declared law on Section 14.

holdings.text: Res judicata does not preclude challenge to a decree on a pure question of law such as the interpretation of Section 14 HSA or where the court sanctioned something illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the above in the very same case of Mathura Prasad  supra , this Court at para 11 held Where, however, the question is one purely of law and it relates to the jurisdiction of the court or a decision of the court sanctioning something which is illegal, by resort to the rule of res judicata a party affected by the decision will not be precluded from challenging the validity of that order under the rule of res judicata,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pure question of law on statutory interpretation; procedural rule cannot override substantive law per Mathura Prasad.

holdings.text: A decree passed without jurisdiction or contrary to law is a nullity and cannot be protected by res judicata, estoppel, or waiver.

anchor.surface_text: When an order is passed without jurisdiction, the same becomes a nullity. When an order is a nullity, it cannot be supported by invoking the procedural principles like, estoppel, waiver or res judicata.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nullity doctrine; res judicata procedural, does not apply to jurisdictional defects per Ashok Leyland and Sonepat Cooperative.

holdings.text: The judgments in Teg Singh and Kesar Singh are not applicable as they are based on special enactment (Punjab Custom Power to Contest Act) not governing this case.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the law laid down by this Court in Teg Singhs case  supra  would support the case of the appellant in this case because the law declared in that case is on the basis of the special enactment referred therein which protected the declaratory rights already obtained by a reversioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction based on inapplicable special law; facts differ from Hindu Succession Act scenario.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the law is clear on this point i.e. if a suit is based on an earlier decree and such decree is contrary to the law prevailing at the time of its consideration as to its legality or is a decree granted by a court which has no jurisdiction to grant such decree, principles of res judicata under Section 11 of the CPC will not be attracted and it is open to the defendant in such suits to establish that the decree relied upon by the plaintiff is not a good law or court granting such decree did not have the jurisdiction to grant such decree.
Hence, the impugned judgment cannot be interfered with. Thus, examined from any angle, we do number find any merit in this appeal.
